{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3381487,"name":"","username":"SammyPants","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sammypants/{size}/188763_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-07T20:30:30.223Z","cooked":"

over the past few years I’ve always structured my code with one code subsystem per one physical subsystem but for my rewrite of our 2024 code I want to think about what other ways I could structure my code. For reference, I’m using command based so a code subsystem is the WPIlib subsystem class. Also, for the most part I’ll be using our 2024 bot as example and talking but general structure advice is also appreciated.

Physically, our bot has 4 subsystems: the drivetrain, the climber, the collector, and the “cobra”. The drivetrain is already done and I don’t think I need to change anything with that. The climber also pretty much does its own thing so it being its own subsystem makes sense too.
Where I get more questions is how do I structure the game piece manipulating subsystems to be logical? for this bot, we have 4 motors controlling 4 functions that interact with notes. a collector to pick up under the bumper, an indexer to hold the note while the shooter revs and such, a shooter that shoots notes and accepts notes from the collector, and a pivot to move the shooter wheels from the collecting position to the speaker position or amp position.
For example, to pick up a note and shoot, the pivot will move the cobra down to collecting position, the shooter, indexer, and collector all move to intake the note and keep moving until the sensor detects a note has just barely passed the note. After that, the pivot will move up to the speaker shot angle while spinning up the shooter and after that, the indexer will push the note into the speaker.

With this, is it best to stick with the physical subsystems as how I split these things or do something like have the pivot be its own subsystem and the indexer, shooter, and collector are all in a “note manipulator” subsystem that has several states to determine what all three sets of wheels are doing?

If none of this makes sense, sorry I threw this together in <10 minutes and it makes sense in my head.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-05-07T20:30:30.223Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":160,"reads":332,"readers_count":331,"score":871.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":465453,"topic_slug":"how-to-structure-robot-code","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51921,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3100 alum (old prog lead)"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-structure-robot-code/465453/1","custom_user_title":"3100 alum (old prog lead)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3381496,"name":"Roman A.","username":"RomanTechPlus","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/romantechplus/{size}/214929_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-07T20:40:08.090Z","cooked":"

There are a lot of approaches to robot code structure, but id generally advise against lumping together a bunch of separate subsystems for the sake of convenience. In general, the aproach we tend to take is putting each subsystem in its own class (with some exceptions) from there, each subsystem is confided to a defined set of “states” that it can be in (think “EXTENED_INTAKEING” for an intake or “TRACKING_TARGET” for a shooter). This allows us to simply coordinate high level actions from mutex garded commad without worrying about low level logic. I.e. you might have a commad that cooridantes several subsystems to intake a note and store it in your robot, but that command is simpy manipulating each subsystem’s goal state.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-05-07T20:48:10.941Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":279,"readers_count":278,"score":55.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":465453,"topic_slug":"how-to-structure-robot-code","display_username":"Roman A.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53160,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-structure-robot-code/465453/2","custom_user_title":"5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3381988,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-08T12:51:47.840Z","cooked":"
SammyPants:

With this, is it best to stick with the physical subsystems as how I split these things or do something like have the pivot be its own subsystem and the indexer, shooter, and collector are all in a “note manipulator” subsystem that has several states to determine what all three sets of wheels are doing?

The physical organization of the robot is not really the thing that’s directly relevant to making this decision. The name Subsystem is a bit misleading here, and we’re thinking of renaming it to Resource in 2027.

The point of Subystem is to define a “lock” for concurrent code, ensuring that sensitive state (often - but not always - representing hardware resources like motors) is not subjected to conflicting commands at the same time. Accordingly, subsystems should be scoped to encapsulate a set of sensitive state that should always be blocked together.

Of course there’s still developer discretion regarding how big these blocks are, but generally the bigger your subsystems the more internal logic must be done inside the subsystem but outside of commands to maintain the contract implied by blocking that much state together.

So, it is a question of balancing the representation between declarative command-centric code (small subsystems) and imperative state-centric code (large subsystems). This comes down to a combination of personal preference and the details of how your robot mechanisms logically interact. There’s no “right answer” (though there are many wrong ones).

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-05-08T12:53:59.418Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":212,"readers_count":211,"score":107.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":465453,"topic_slug":"how-to-structure-robot-code","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-structure-robot-code/465453/3","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3381994,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-08T13:14:34.787Z","cooked":"

One of things we discovered is that all our sensors went into their own class - even if they are attached to a subsystem. Often, other systems need to know sensor status for hand offs of game pieces, etc. Since no subsystem needs to “own” the sensors to read them, having them all in their own subsystem means any command can get the info without having to own it.

Oblarg mentioned above the misconception of having something called a subsystem. For instance, in '22 we found that we could just lower our intake to pick up cubes. However, prior to figuring that out, the intake was part of the arm because we assumed the two would always move together.

So while the arm / intake was in the physical world “one” subsystem, the reality was it needed to be two (call them resources) because we need to use them independently.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-05-08T13:16:38.505Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":167,"readers_count":166,"score":53.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":465453,"topic_slug":"how-to-structure-robot-code","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-structure-robot-code/465453/4","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3381995,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-08T13:17:14.473Z","cooked":"

The WPILib team generally suggests doing this with public-facing triggers in the scope of the subsystem, if the sensor “naturally” lives there (in a conceptual sense):

github.com

wpilibsuite/allwpilib/blob/main/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/rapidreactcommandbot/RapidReactCommandBot.java#L54


      
    
          
  1.  *
    2. 
          
  2.  * <p>Event binding methods are available on the {@link Trigger} class.
    3. 
          
  3.  */
    4. 
          
  4. public void configureBindings() {
    5. 
          
  5.   // Automatically run the storage motor whenever the ball storage is not full,
    6. 
          
  6.   // and turn it off whenever it fills. Uses subsystem-hosted trigger to
    7. 
          
  7.   // improve readability and make inter-subsystem communication easier.
    8. 
          
  8.   m_storage.hasCargo.whileFalse(m_storage.runCommand());
    9. 
          
  9. 
          
  10.   // Automatically disable and retract the intake whenever the ball storage is full.
    11. 
          
  11.   m_storage.hasCargo.onTrue(m_intake.retractCommand());
    12. 
          
  12. 
          
  13.   // Control the drive with split-stick arcade controls
    14. 
          
  14.   m_drive.setDefaultCommand(
    15. 
          
  15.       m_drive.arcadeDriveCommand(
    16. 
          
  16.           () -> -m_driverController.getLeftY(), () -> -m_driverController.getRightX()));
    17. 
          
  17. 
          
  18.   // Deploy the intake with the X button
    19. 
          
  19.   m_driverController.x().onTrue(m_intake.intakeCommand());
    20. 
          
  20.   // Retract the intake with the Y button
    21. 
          
  21.   m_driverController.y().onTrue(m_intake.retractCommand());
    22.

For sensors that still do not really fit anywhere (I find there are typically at least a couple of these), having a separate “sensors” class is often appropriate (or else they can just float in RobotContainer).

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-05-08T13:17:14.473Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":165,"readers_count":164,"score":123.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":465453,"topic_slug":"how-to-structure-robot-code","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/blob/main/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/rapidreactcommandbot/RapidReactCommandBot.java#L54","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"allwpilib/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/rapidreactcommandbot/RapidReactCommandBot.java at main · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub","clicks":13}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7841,"username":"Tom_Line","name":"Tom Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-structure-robot-code/465453/5","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3382010,"name":"Waz","username":"Waz","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/7cd45c/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-08T13:39:12.513Z","cooked":"

I have been thinking about this very question a bit lately. I have advocated approaching this problem in much the same way Roman has. Right now, I am experimenting with a different approach. Rather than defining a state machine for each subsystem involved in note handling (intake, indexer, arm, shooter), I am defining one state machine for the note (an enum EMPTY, INTAKING, STORING, STORED, TARGETING, SHOOTING, OUTTAKING). The subsystems simply react to note state changes and at times automatically change the current state. Some note state transitions will come from driver button presses.

So far, I have only written code for the intake and it looks pretty clean. It is however, very new and untested (just “finished” it minutes ago). Here is the intake in Python. Note that each note state enum value can return its associated trigger.

from commands2 import Command
from commands2.button import Trigger
from commands2.subsystem import Subsystem
from intakeConstants import IntakeConstants
from phoenix5 import SupplyCurrentLimitConfiguration, TalonSRX, TalonSRXControlMode
from wpilib import DigitalInput

from constants import Constants
from note.noteAPI import NoteAPI
from note.noteState import NoteState


class Intake(Subsystem):
    def __init__(self):
        self.__intakeMotor = TalonSRX(Constants.CANIDs.kIntakeMotorID)
        self.__intakeMotor.configFactoryDefault()
        self.__noteAPI = NoteAPI()

        supply_configs = SupplyCurrentLimitConfiguration(
            True,
            IntakeConstants.kCurrentLimitAmps,
            IntakeConstants.kCurrentThresholdAmps,
            IntakeConstants.kCurrentThresholdTimeSec,
        )
        self.__intakeMotor.configSupplyCurrentLimit(supply_configs)

        self.__intakeBeamBreak = DigitalInput(Constants.DIOs.kIntakeBeamBreakDIO)
        self.__initStateMachine()

    def __getIntakeBeamBreakState(self) -> bool:
        return not bool(self.__intakeBeamBreak.get())

    def __intake(self) -> Command:
        return self.run(
            lambda: self.__intakeMotor.set(
                TalonSRXControlMode.PercentOutput,
                IntakeConstants.kSpeedPercentOutput,
            )
        ).withName("Intake.intake")

    def __outtake(self) -> Command:
        return self.run(
            lambda: self.__intakeMotor.set(
                TalonSRXControlMode.PercentOutput,
                -IntakeConstants.kSpeedPercentOutput,
            )
        ).withName("Intake.outtake")

    def stop(self) -> Command:
        return self.run(
            lambda: self.__intakeMotor.set(TalonSRXControlMode.PercentOutput, 0.0)
        ).withName("Intake.stop")

    def __initStateMachine(self):
        self.setDefaultCommand(self.stopCommand())
        NoteState.EMPTY.getTrigger().or_(NoteState.STORED.getTrigger()).onTrue(
            self.stop()
        )
        # TODO check if we need jog going from STORING to STORED and add state
        NoteState.INTAKING.getTrigger().or_(NoteState.STORING.getTrigger()).or_(
            NoteState.TARGETING.getTrigger()
        ).or_(NoteState.SHOOTING.getTrigger()).onTrue(self.__intake())
        NoteState.OUTTAKING.getTrigger().onTrue(self.__outtake())

        Trigger(
            (self.__noteAPI.getNoteState is NoteState.INTAKING)
            and self.__getIntakeBeamBreakState
        ).onTrue(lambda: self.__noteAPI.setNoteState(NoteState.STORING))

At this point I do not know which approach I like better, and probably will not know until I get this to a testable state and on the robot.

The other relevant change is hinted at in the imports. Rather than one big constants file (I have always hated that), there is one constants file per subsystem and one much smaller global constants file. The only thing in the global constants file will be things like CAN ids, DIO port assignments, etc. That is, values the have to be managed across subsystems to avoid conflicts.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-05-08T13:39:12.513Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":73.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":465453,"topic_slug":"how-to-structure-robot-code","display_username":"Waz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20488,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-structure-robot-code/465453/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3382594,"name":"","username":"SammyPants","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sammypants/{size}/188763_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-09T13:55:21.349Z","cooked":"

Going off this, a more logical organization would be to have subsystems for drivetrain, climber, collector, pivot, and “shooter” (would include the indexer too).
That way the collector can always do its own thing (run outwards to reject notes) the pivot can too, and the shooter and indexer are forced to always work together (so the note doesn’t accidentally get ejected)

This sounds like a very reasonable way to carve the problem-space, yeah.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-05-09T13:55:54.335Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":71,"readers_count":70,"score":19.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":465453,"topic_slug":"how-to-structure-robot-code","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51921,"username":"SammyPants","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sammypants/{size}/188763_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-structure-robot-code/465453/8","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3382597,"name":"","username":"SammyPants","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sammypants/{size}/188763_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-09T13:56:22.194Z","cooked":"
